data.title: A great way to spend 30 minutes
data.text: The docent was very knowledgeable.  The lightship is not very large and only 1 deck is open to tourists, but it is very interesting.  I had never heard of a lightship until I moved to Portsmouth and I retired from the Navy.  Well worth the time spent.

data.title: A part of Coast Guard History
data.text: Went with two grandchildren (11 & 13).  Everyone enjoyed seeing the ship and the guide made everything interesting.

data.title: Nice museum
data.text: Easy, quick visit with children in tow.  Intersting for all.  Nice way to get to tourma tug boat up close and personal.

data.title: You get a true historical feel
data.text:
This place makes you appreciate what those Coast Guard sailors had to live with back in the day before all our modern conveniences.
I learned a lot from Bruce, the gentleman who met us at the door (or should I say, Freezer Door - you need to go there to find out more about that statement.)

data.title: Nice piece of military and local history
data.text:
This lightship was built in 1915 and until 1964, was called Stonehorse, Charles, and Overfalls before it was named Portsmouth (for its last port of Portsmouth, VA).  In 1964, it was made into a museum.  In 1989, it was named a National Historic Landmark.

You can tour the main floor, but not the top deck.  Also, look up visiting times, because they are limited.  It is not stroller or wheelchair friendly and it is surrounded by a hotel and an apartment building.  Parking is odd.

data.title: Light ship Portsmouth Museum
data.text: Great outside activity.. Very good place to take a few pictures. would recomment the visit to anyone.

data.title: Very Eduacational!
data.text: I happened to stayed in Chesapeake the night before. Since I wanted to visit the Ships on the water but when I got there they happened to be far away on the water. As I drove around I stumble on this beautiful ship with lots of history. Is was born in 1815, dock in 3 different places in the states and every time it was move, will have a different name. Got to see the bunks where military will sleep, come to find out that this assignment was the worse for enlisted men at the time. It was very lonely and with 45 people on board, cramp!

data.title: Unique, and interesting!
data.text:
I visited on a rainy Monday morning. No one else came while I was there, so I got a personal tour.  The guide was friendly and knowledgeable, and the boat was interesting.  It's in good repair, and appears as it would have been while in use.

It was fun to walk through the boat and think about how the men would have lived.

It's also in a nice setting--we enjoyed walking through historic old Portsmouth.

data.title: Pleasant surprise
data.text: It was truly a pleasant surprise to visit the lightship... the tour is free so is the visit.. i donated 5 dollars... the ship is truly an engineering marvel ofnits of it's time.. yo live in those conditions is truly remarkable... i tip my hat to all of those who served our nation in those conditions...

data.title: Walking around after hours, nice photo op.
data.text: Strange to see a boat just sitting there, interesting read on the history and what these types of boats where used for.

data.title: Quick fun tour!
data.text: No admission cost, donation jar was out. Our tour guide was Les and he was great taking us throughout the lightship!

data.title: Short walk from Renaissance Portsmouth-Norfolk Waterfront Hotel
data.text: We were greeted by a tour guide who offered either to let us wonder around and look for our selves or to give us a 25 minute tour.  we opted for the tour and it was very nice maybe a little longer than 25 minutes, but very interesting.  It was free and well  worth the visit.  They do have a donation box so stop in and pay what you think it was worth.

data.title: Interesting
data.text: Very interesting visit.  Lots of info.  The staff told us lots of info about the ship and how hard life was for the men on the ships

data.title: Nice to go to for maritime lovers
data.text: Just a cool little boat to check out if you're into visiting museums and like boats. Very easy to find and something to do in downtown Portsmouth.

data.title: If you are into ships or light houses, it a must stop
data.text: It was interesting to see how this men did there job and how they lived while on the ship. Must have been boring sitting out in the ocean and making sure the light was on all night. It was right under our hotel window

data.title: Limited
data.text: Brief but interesting.  Can only see the outside and the pond it sits in is not keep clean or fresh.  Worth a brief stroll by.

data.title: Great to learn about the history of lightships
data.text: This is an unique treasure. A ship moored on the waterfront, with guides who tell how lightships kept the coast safe for ships. Outstanding displays and eager guides make this a must-see.

data.title: Interesting!
data.text:
We were the only people in the boat, so we got all of the attention from the man giving us the tour inside. He was very informative and made it interesting by telling us the history behind some of the things on board and showing us how things were used. You could tell he knows a lot about the history of the boat and he knows what he is talking about! He took the time to ask us questions about what we knew and to demonstrate how oil was carried up the ship, how the cook worked, the anchor, lighthouse. 

Most of the boat is blocked off, so it is a very short tour - maybe 10-15 minutes - but it was worth it and you will definitely learn something new. We took the boat tour in conjunction with the shipyard museum, so we got to read a little about the boat and then actually get to go inside of one.

data.title: Well worth a visit, highly engaging
data.text: like many other reviewers, I'd never heard of lightships until Portsmouth. It was a quiet day, so I received a personal tour showing me round the ship. $4 for entry to this and the naval museum. I'd start there first as it has some info about the ship's origins. I'd highly recommend a visit.

data.title: Not open to tour.
data.text: We did get to take some pictures of the outside but it was closed to tour. We saw some of the info on lightships at Shipyard Museum. We were disappointed it was closed to tour.
